> [anonymouslogin](#comment_117_17AMQVbBa12XB3xFWKDnP2dCEx92TaiY7X): a great idea, download random sites from zeronet

But there is no index of all zites right? There are [zite directories](/1TaLkFrMwvbNsooF4ioKAY9EuxTBTjipT/?Topic:1524949682_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS/ZeroNet+sites+directories), [ZeroName](/1Name2NXVi1RDPDgf5617UoW7xA6YrhM9F) and there already are the bash scripts you can run to let your computer periodically download zites added to these directories. One of such scripts is [here](/1LtvsjbtQ2tY7SCtCZzC4KhErqEK3bXD4n), but i would replace:
curl --silent http://$ZERO_HOST:43110/$SITE > /dev/null
by:
timeout 200 python $ZERO_DIR/zeronet.py --silent siteDownload "$SITE" 2>&1 >/dev/null
(verify the path to python and that the zeronet.py exist ; append " &" if want to run multiple concurrent site downloads)
[The full linux bash script here](/1TaLkFrMwvbNsooF4ioKAY9EuxTBTjipT/?Topic:1546121685_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS/Linux+bash+script+to+download+sites+recently+added+to+New+ZeroNet+Sites)

Also i would not want to let my computer download everything blindly, because i think it is not moral to seed bad content.

I wish these features:
- Deleting unwanted site and sub-page and images should be easier than now (example hover the (0) button to show extended menu with options to delete site/current page or all media on site/current page)
- [Antibot system](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/1310)
- Community managed blacklist where blacklisted sites will be accessible to anyone, but the warning & most common/voted reasons will be shown. User can proceed opening the site, but it will not be seeded until he/she vote the site is not bad & he want to seed it. A few anti-blacklist votes will remove the blacklisting (voters have to be verified, see above linked antibot system).

A first site i would vote for blacklisting: 18GnfE7WaWBZGEjigo8GcKWhWjc7rUfZWd

There will always be a bot or a human that will seed the "bad" site. The system i described would not hurt freedom of speech much because user can still visit blacklisted site by just clicking a button. The point was to place a warning and prevent user accidentaly/unknowingly seed bad content. But as i am thinking about this, the blacklist warnings can even increase users attention to stay on the site and study it more, though it can lead to less peers of the "bad" site, because only bots and people willing to seed it will be the peers.

> I'd say, we should stay true to our roots

i think it is a good point, it should probably stay uncensored even the site being drug selling, racist, holocaust denying :-S it is problem of the zeronet maintainer i guess. I see it unfair if less skilled ZN users will accidentaly seed drug selling site, etc. or young people accidentaly visit porn site.

1526885161_12gAes6NzDS9E2q6Q1UXrpUdbPS6n.body:
Plugins can be enabled by removing "disabled-" from its folder name (ZeroNet/core/plugins/disabled-pluginname) 

**UiPassword** is a plugin that will protect Zeronet User Interface by password set during Zeronet start (use zeronet startup parameter: --ui_password passwordhere
or add new line to zeronet.conf below [global] line: ui_password = passwordhere
This plugin is used in [public ZN proxies](/1TaLkFrMwvbNsooF4ioKAY9EuxTBTjipT/?Topic:1524212586_19H2XXg8jU9v8JstBejNbfAEaBNtMHgrtS#comment_220_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS) so only one with password can use it. [source](https://zeronet.readthedocs.io/en/latest/faq/#is-it-possible-to-install-zeronet-to-a-remote-machine)

**Multiuser** plugin allows one to switch between multiple Zeronet identities/usernames/IDs, check:
[[Tutorial] How To Configure ZeroNet To Work With Multiple Users](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1648uDJu8HaSjiYR6p8KJMGtKGQyUdFNqS/?Post:11:[Tutorial]+How+To+Configure+ZeroNet+To+Work+With+Multiple+Users)
[Using the Multiuser plugin](/eventi.bit/?Post:3:Using+the+Multiuser+plugin)

**StemPort** ??

**DonationMessage** Puts a little donation link to the bottom of every page (disabled by default) ([source](/Blog.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Post:22))

**Dnschain** plugin is not working well, so not advised to use ([source](/1TaLkFrMwvbNsooF4ioKAY9EuxTBTjipT/?Topic:2_1FYXQGLBeNabf5jZHgP4CwzbmJSKaK4oMz#comment_644_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj))

**Bootstrapper** In-network bootstrapping was added some months ago (Bootstrapper plugin), it allows to support Tor nodes + SSL cert pinning (Secure, MITM proof connection). ... You can run your own bootstrapper node on non-internet networks: enable Bootsrapper plugin and add the address to --trackers. ([source](/1TaLkFrMwvbNsooF4ioKAY9EuxTBTjipT/?Topic:6_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh#comment_522_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj))
Another info [here](/1MeFqFfFFGQfa1J3gJyYYUvb5Lksczq7nH/?Post/12h51ug6CcntU2aiBjhP8Ns2e5VypbWWtv/1PSaHi14Xh4Kjo3yyjDgbRtj4YLQgWV4QJ/1516695886) and [here](/1MeFqFfFFGQfa1J3gJyYYUvb5Lksczq7nH/?Post/1RedkCkVaXuVXrqCMpoXQS29bwaqsuFdL/1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj/1486950059#) (search "bootstrap" on that pages)

I do not know details, just linking to sources.

1528088389_12gAes6NzDS9E2q6Q1UXrpUdbPS6n.body: @krixano Hi, and what if i do not have any repository on my PC yet (i mean i never installed git on that Linux PC) and i only know which github project i want to clone. Can you suggest steps to do?

>$ apt install git
>$ git clone YOUR_PROJECT_ON_GITHUB
>$ cd YOUR_PROJECT_ON_GITHUB

For n00bs in git on Windows, here is how on Windows i filled my Gitcenter repo by third party Github repo content using above Krixano tutorial commands and Gitcenter suggested comments (there is really nothing new just maybe a bit more comment on how it worked):

1. DL git software (~40MB) from https://git-scm.com/download/win
2. Go to installation folder, and run git-cmd.exe
3. On a Github project page, example [here](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroTalk/), i click "Clone or Download" green button and copy provided http URL which ends by .git
4. In previously opened git-cmd.exe console, executed command: `git clone https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroTalk.git`
It finish and create local project "ZeroTalk"
5. execute command: `cd ZeroTalk`
(mentioned by GitCenter, unsure if needed)
--now Krixano guide from first post of this topic--
6. exec. command: `git remote add gitcenter T:\ZeroNet\data\1KR7WWJZwdezqEdSCPtChQGVdfgnBVhMPK\zerotalk-2017.git`
(replace by yours info, as Krixano describe. Note that GitCenter can give you path with "/" slash for linux, but Windows path may need to have "\" slash)
7. command: `git push gitcenter --force`
(force overwites everything in ones gitcenter repository)

and i see on Gitcenter the repo shows new files like on Github

> It's zite owners decision to filter or not to filter, and in my opinion it is good to tell site visitor if such filters exist.
Yes and maybe if users have option to disable filtering that is enabled by default - users by default do not see "bad" content. (Admin can hide "bad" content or delete it; hiding "bad" content for all users feature is already used by [Millchan](127.0.0.1:43110/1ADQAHsqsie5PBeQhQgjcKmUu3qdPFg6aA/) - discussion board owner has right to hide certain user post or all posts of a certain user from all users to see. He can do it in his own discussion board. Users can though disable this filtering, there is a tickbox on the bottom of the discussion topic at Millchan)

> We still need to work on a report function so that users themselves can do all the work of taking down unwanted links.
YES to that, it would allow "spammed", admin abandoned sites to stay organized. BUT such [community moderation system](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/1086) would have to be sophisticated not to allow "low trust" users, bots to damage sites by freely removing any content. Further details are linked from the page i link above.

I think users should be informed before seeing adult content. If adult content publisher do nto do this, i think community should vote for the content be marked NSFW/Porn (some discussion about this [here](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1MeFqFfFFGQfa1J3gJyYYUvb5Lksczq7nH/?Post/1SunAWK2VUT9GQK32MpwRfFPVgcBSJN9a/15tQJFZZ7KVYMX6XPUkcs138LcgDQ2zVcL/1529968417) ).

Users can now create lists of bad sites and other users can subscribe to them so they are warned before visiting bad site: [here is discussion about that](/1TaLkFrMwvbNsooF4ioKAY9EuxTBTjipT/?Topic:1530020784_1AHEQxyRG9s6owyJHShB4U4rg9GL5FMX5K)

1530712796_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRF.body:
Indeed the clearnet can host almost anything if one find right server provider. Biggest **positive of the Zeronet** (is it deepweb?) is that the sites are served by its visitors in my opinion so it is distributed.

**The freedom of speech** can be on the clearnet too with right hosting providers. But Zeronet is more convenient i guess (no server costs, less chances for the content to be taken down - at least i hope).

Note that in case of Zeronet, the **anonymity** can be the issue, because it is not the hosting provider IP that is serving the "bad" or sensitive content, but the IP assigned directly to the person. Unless one pay attention to use Tor always mode (set maybe in zeronet.conf or [ZeroHello](/) top bar)

Quoting from the data/users/content.json of the "New ZeroNet Sites":
  "permission_rules": {

    "max_size": 10000

1532820348_1BBLpFiExm8RJzxZmmw7GYoP2jd8e.body:
I may not be well informed, but i will tell what i think are differences between Tor hidden service site and the Zeronet zite:

1) DECENTRALIZATION/UPTIME - Tor hidden service is not decentralised (is more vulnerable to stop working in my opinion), Zeronet website is distributed by many people and allows offline & LAN browsing
2) DISK SPACE AND BANDWIDTH - Tor hidden service need to store all data and cover all bandwidth of all visiting users, Zeronet site peers may have only certain files, and rest of the files is fetched from other users who have the rest, Zeronet site bandwith is split among peers
3) NUMBER OF USERS - Number of Tor network users is significantly higher so people present website to a bigger audience.
4) NUMBER OF DEVELOPERS - Tor is older project developed by significantly higher number of people, Zeronet only by a few people so far
5) CONTENT MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS - huge advantage of a Tor hidden service is that it can host known content management systems like Wordpress, vBulletin, PHPBB. Zeronet is distributed so it do not use PHP, it use its own CMS's built using [HTML, CSS, Javascript, SQL, Zeronet API](https://zeronet.readthedocs.io/en/latest/site_development/getting_started/). Setting up own site like a Blog or the forum is easier on ZeroNet (just click Clone button), but then you have to edit html, js, css in case you need modifications.

1532999851_1JHx7fetxzMnUyQ5bUpNLAKAW9VEZ.body:
I may be wrong, but i think hub is a site that is made to store data. Is merger-site a hub?
Example in case of Me.ZeroNetwork.bit (or its clones like styromaniac said - peeper.bit, sakana.bit) the hub is the site which is used in the background to store your zerome profile data (posts, comments, images) and (maybe unfortunately) it stores also information about where these posts should be located, so [when you migrate to different hub, you may face issues](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroMe/issues/109). Anyone can create hub (by cloning existing hub site), and set its limits. Some default hubs has super low limit for user submitted content like 60KB so you have to manually contact admin and hope he still use zeronet and raise it for you in order you can continue posting on ZeroMe, else you see error "Include too large, Content Signing failed". Soit is wise to select hub with large limits when you initialy create new profile on ZeroMe (try GigabyteHub or Kaffie hub or 127.0.0.1:43110/0pan.bit/) and post feedback if something wrong.

When you reply someone on ZeroMe, the comment is added to HIS hub, (which he used to create his profile at) and also to "your" hub (content.json file), which may be problem, because you may reach limits of these users hub and admin of these hubs may no longer be available to raise them (@nofish).

> [leftside](#comment_160_16dEowtNbV89NxPcDrAKkmnuXtiJVoVcDm): So do you mean that it is technically possible as well as without being traced by the communist regime?

If you are Chinese and access the server/site that is outside of China and the [VPN/encryption supported proxy](/1LfvE91ZF18jdG3wW62Dw7NtfTZh737KPL/?Topic:1519759218_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS/Which+VPN+proxy+setup+is+your+favorite) is outside of the censor country too, then i think yes, because the data from ones computer to the VPN server (located in free country) are encrypted.
I have not seen any information censor ISP's would decrypt VPN traffic on the fly.

For example ZeroNet traffic is [NOT encrypted](/1TaLkFrMwvbNsooF4ioKAY9EuxTBTjipT/?Topic:1518461623_1R67TfYzNkCnh89EFfGmXn5LMb4hXaMRQ#comment_140_1QEfmMwKVxgR4rkREbdJYjgUmF3Zy8pwHt) from what i read (unless one use VPN or other encrypted proxy) on their computer so all traffic including ZN goes thru it. ZN traffic is also not anyonymous (unless your set Tor Always on [ZeroHello](/) or use VPN/anonymous proxy to hide your real IP). But thanks to VPNs located in free countries, i think it is prety safe, one have to use VPN killswitch so it prevent unencrypted data (usually low importance data) leaking and the making sure the DNS lookups are done by the VPN server not client located in restricted country. To verify IP leak, there are many tools: https://ipleak.net

1533160269_1JHx7fetxzMnUyQ5bUpNLAKAW9VEZ.body:
Per the [FAQ](https://beakerbrowser.com/docs/faq/#is-the-dat-network-anonymous) **Beaker Browser says that users are NOT anonymous, their IP is public to other peers**. On the other hand, ZeroNet integrates Tor which allows anonymity (selecting "Tor Always" mode on the top of the [ZeroHello](/) page - which means slower connections).

**In Firefox without Beaker browser**
Firefox v. 59+ allows creating browser extensions for dat:// and ipfs:// protocols ([source](/1EiMAqhd6sMjPG2tznkkGXxhdwFBDdeqT9/?Post:71)).
And these were already created:
https://addons.mozilla.org/firefox/search/?q=dat%3A%2F%2F&type=extension
https://addons.mozilla.org/firefox/search/?q=ipfs%3A%2F%2F&type=extension
FF extension does not obviously include whole implementation of the P2P system. So one have to manualy install and run the appropriate P2P application + helper: https://datfox-sammacbeth.hashbase.io/how-to-install-dat-fox-helper . So probably better to use Beaker browser which has all built in.

**List of some dat:// sites**: https://github.com/beakerbrowser/explore

> [nicwow](#comment_21_1JHx7fetxzMnUyQ5bUpNLAKAW9VEZdbFMa): Thanks for the summary. I never knew that ZeroNet didn't have encryption.
I was wrong! After searching "zeronet encrypted TLS" on ZeroHello, i found a [blog post](/Blog.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Post:128) of the Zeronet developer saying: "Implicit TLS by default on connections: **ZeroNet connections now looks and acts exactly like HTTPS connections** which makes it harder to detect and improves the privacy."

"--force_encryption argument to disable non-encrypted connection fallback for clients that do not support TLS"

[TLS is a secure encryption](https://security.stackexchange.com/questions/15527/is-tls-flawless-enough-to-prevent-eavesdropping-carried-out-by-an-isp) of the transfered data.

[How to use dat:// protocol to share single file or folder between peers](/1LfvE91ZF18jdG3wW62Dw7NtfTZh737KPL/?Topic:1534502068_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS/How+to+use+dat+protocol+to+share+single+file+or+folder+between+peers)

@leftside
In the [browser compatibility section](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Supported_media_formats#Browser_compatibility), Mozilla says:
H.264 and MP3 is not built directly into Firefox. Instead it relies on support from the OS or hardware (the hardware also needs to be able to support the profile used to encode the video, in the case of MP4). Firefox supports these formats on the following platforms: Windows Vista+ since Firefox 22.0, Android since Firefox 20.0, Firefox OS since Firefox 15.0, Linux since Firefox 26.0 (relies on GStreamer codecs) and OS X 10.7 since Firefox 35.0.

https://caniuse.com/#feat=mpeg4 says "Firefox supports H.264 on Windows 7 and later since version 21. Firefox supports H.264 on Linux since version 26 if the appropriate gstreamer plug-ins are installed."

It may be interesting to know what your device, OS is and what do you see when you do ffmpeg -i on other .mp4 videos that are playable via browser. What are differences in the output. What about trying to re-encode the video using aac audio codec as quantumkitty suggested? Will it work?

@leftside this recent video with AAC sound plays OK in my Firefox beta. The previous video with mp3 was encoded by same software you used to encode in AAC? If yes, then it may be a bug in Firefox/Tor browser? https://support.mozilla.org / https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/
In my previous comment i mentioned that the Firefox supports x264+mp3 on "Windows Vista+ since Firefox 22.0, Android since Firefox 20.0, Firefox OS since Firefox 15.0, Linux since Firefox 26.0 (relies on GStreamer codecs) and OS X 10.7 since Firefox 35.0." Not sure what your OS is (if it fits the supported category).

Sorry if i hijack your thread. **What is the fastest way to test whether two LAN computers properly utilize local peer feature of the Zeronet?**

1) opening command line and doing "ping lanpeerIPhere" (ping 192.168.0.9) or using netcat (nc) linux command somehow to [see if LAN peer is reachable](https://duckduckgo.com/?q=using+netcat+to+test+LAN+specific+port&t=ffab&atb=v126-6__&ia=web).
2) if other LAN device is reachable, then load some website on first LAN device and on ther devices delete this site (if exist) and then access the site defining the LAN peer address like: http://127.0.0.1:43110/siteaddress/?zeronet_peer=192.168.0.9:43110,192.168.0.8:4300 (i have not tested this)

- LAN peer is prioritized over internet peer

> [leftside](#comment_229_16dEowtNbV89NxPcDrAKkmnuXtiJVoVcDm): without --tor disable when the internet goes offline zeronet cannot find local peer at all. To do the local peer discovery, you have to restart zeronet with --tor disable. [...]

- "If you enable Tor always mode, then your client will only accept connections from the Tor network. So local peer discovery and local connections will not work."

In the mine linked topic (above), the user "test20180221" has problem with local peers also even he is using Tor: available mode. (unsure if issue is really in his zeronet or firewall etc.)..

@leftside

So even if you update zeronet on all computers to be latest version and use --tor disable, and you can ping all your devices each other, or can see their open zeronet ports (not sure which, in [/Stats](/Stats) some port is mentioned.. on Linux one can discover it by doing "netstat -tulnp" on localhost or from remote by doing portscan using "nmap remoteiphere"), but zeronet still not doing local connection? Linux PC debug.log:

# How zerome a hubs works
**I think the structure is** that when you first create your zerome profile, you have to select a hub which will become storage of your posts and images. You have to choose right hub carefuly before creating a profile on it, because some hubs admins are no longer available so once you reach the small user quota of the hub, you can no longer add new content! ("Include too large" error) see [ideas to fix this](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroMe/issues/123), regarding comments on other people posts, i agree these are added to the hubs of these users.

Hubs are storage sites, zerome is a platform that connecting the storages.

Related topic: [How Does ZeroMe be able to reach hubs you didnt seed](/1TaLkFrMwvbNsooF4ioKAY9EuxTBTjipT/?Topic:1524573807_1AHEQxyRG9s6owyJHShB4U4rg9GL5FMX5K)

4_13Z7XxTa7JuFat3KzzMWu3onwM6biLuurJ.body:
Not sure, but when my data folder is around 34GB (million files maybe) and setting up 10 minute cron, it may run several rsync at same time (if that can be issue) so on slow HDD, maybe better to run script manually for the first time, and then manually again second run to see the time needed for one sync. Then base the cronjob repetition on second sync time. If the cronjob time is too large, maybe computer will erase cache and syncing will be much slower.

On Windows i am using software called FreeFileSync, it also is able to do quite fast synchronization like a rsync.

1534971223_1zsJv9enraYHekB8HAYN5nBhjdrTs.body:
@scararoot Zeronet is using torrent protocol, torrent trackers to connect peers. In [/Config](/Config), we apparently can manage how Tor is used in Zeronet. Per the description, using Tor network will make connections slower for the peers to connect and data transfer of the big file may be slower too in my opinion. It is cost of the anonymity i think.

I also think it is good to have Tor in state "enabled", because i think that way one can connect normal peers + ones that use only Tor,. The result is i can connect more peers. I noticed Zeronet's tor.exe process is using alot of CPU (i am having alot of Zeronet sites hosted).

> I don't know if disabled disallows Tor peers to connect to your node

I have "Tor: disabled" currently and on [/Stats](/Stats) i see 22 connections, no .onion peer, usually it was like 50% .onion peers, tor.exe process is not running so i assume no Tor peer can connect me in this state, but Nofish [here](/1TaLkFrMwvbNsooF4ioKAY9EuxTBTjipT/?Topic:17_14XxpXNGMLsyeQxikacrbQnAFXVyhN5Ngx) describe Tor modes (enabled, always, disabled), so according to that, it seems that Tor peers can connect clearnet peers which have PORT: OPEN (on [ZeroHello](/) header) and they will connect them no mater if they have Tor disabled, because according to nofish, they connect thru Tor exit node which has public IPv4.

Peer exchange / PEX at Github: https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/79

> [styromaniac](#comment_28_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRFtVBhd): non-Tor peers ... can forward data obtained from my node to Tor peers.

You mean like this?
Me (Tor: Disabled + Port: closed) publish some change to other peers (except in my case not those that have tor: always) and some of these peers have tor: enabled (which allows them to connect both non-tor and tor peers) and so they propagate my modification even to the tor peer/s and so this way the modification will spread to all peer types? Only it can take longer time and slower, right?

In my first comment in this topic i mentioned "tor: enabled" mode is the best and i still standing behind that claim, because you will be able to connect more peers (directly), and it can be essential in helping new sites (or any new content) to get seeders (if initial seeder is using Tor: always, and you use Tor: disabled, we can not interconnect, if i am a first peer and there is no Tor: enabled peer that would help distribute initial seeder content to me)

1516559181_18cuVo4ak3NDVwhTCXE5WtUc4q5ZX.body:
From [official docs](https://zeronet.readthedocs.io/en/latest/faq/#how-to-make-zeronet-work-with-tor-under-linux):

**sudo apt install tor**
**sudo nano /etc/tor/torrc**
Remove the # character from lines ControlPort 9051 and CookieAuthentication 1 (line ~57)
**/etc/init.d/tor restart**
Add permission yourself to read the auth cookie by:
**sudo usermod -a -G debian-tor YOURLINUXUSERNAMEHERE**
(if you are not on Debian check the file's user group by):
**ls -al /var/run/tor/control.authcookie**
Logout/Login with your user to apply group changes

i think it should work on Arch too it worked on Ubuntu

1542892944_1HiF6gUThBQQqghUPLxc7h2uupMJx.body:
**Regarding backup**, I backup whole data dir from time to time and users.json, sites.json, filters.json more often. I recommend to do some versioning (meaning keep more versions of the backup for the case when the latest has error in itself).

Regarding **issues with propagation between 2 computers**, make sure both computers can ping each other (search: how to ping other computer). You can then check the ZeroNet/log/debug.log to see what Zeronet was doing. If computers are in same LAN, you may disconnect internet to remove clutter out of the log. The peers propagation may fail due to several reasons, i remember these (i may be wrong):
- other device was not a direct peer when you published a content so it needs more time to receive the update from other peers
- both pc have closed port and one or both does not have tor enabled (these facts can be discovered on the top of ZeroHello page) - propagation of content in such case can be delayed
- you are using a VPN on both devices which have same IP
If you are interested in testing the issue, [here is my post](/1TaLkFrMwvbNsooF4ioKAY9EuxTBTjipT/?Topic:1534145930_16dEowtNbV89NxPcDrAKkmnuXtiJVoVcDm#comment_449_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS) where i written how i did it

**Regarding how to get latest ZeroNet version**, open [ZeroHello](/) and next to the logo are three dots, click it to open menu where you click the version number to update. Else in Zeronet directory is update script (update.py), on linux i open terminal, go to the zeronet directory and execute command: python update.py
btw: ZN latest files are at the time of writing here:
https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/releases/latest
https://zeronet.io/

1543348094_16VrCKQQiVZpJ6S5xJASR8LCFLv24.body: @anon202010102 someone more qualified may reply, but this is what i know so far as an amateur user: > "Additionally, you can't submit content without using an ID, even for anonymous submission." You can use ZeroNet in Tor browser and enable "TOR: Always" mode on the top of [ZeroHello](/) page and then register new ID at /zeroid.bit to be anonymous (?). ZeroNet will make all connections thru the Tor i guess and that should keep you anonymous, but still people can "connect" your content and give them image about you. - On various sites you can use various ID providers to appear under multiple identities. For example ZeroVoat generates own identity, Millchan also. - you can use [multiuser_local switch](/1TaLkFrMwvbNsooF4ioKAY9EuxTBTjipT/?Topic:1521308711_128dbVaHobAMsFW25rUVyFxwdCvvfkidzT#comment_217_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS) which will allow you to switch various identities via ZeroHello page. I am using it and you just add the "multiuser_local" line into zeronet.conf. Then on ZeroHello, you can switch identity. Example one ID you use for serious content, other for questionable. PS: @Krixano started some decentralized ID authority site http://127.0.0.1:43110/1GTVetvjTEriCMzKzWSP9FahYoMPy6BG1P/?/create-id using custom PeerMessage plugin (though nothing like that is bundled into ZeroNet by default). > inject arbitrary images and videos at any time, force other clients to make requests to arbitrary addresses on the clearnet by injecting tags, etc. - [Lola](/1MeFqFfFFGQfa1J3gJyYYUvb5Lksczq7nH/?Profile/1BLueGvui1GdbtsjcKqCf4F67uKfritG49/1KuwwnkAtVrfnyhv8pyGRxLqzNZbEkJt2u/lola@zeroid.bit) is creating [Zeronet Browser](https://github.com/rllola/ZeronetBrowser) that may block clearnet traffic in the future - I am guessing there may already be plugins that would do the same for Firefox, Chrome. - Or one can use Tor Browser to keep some anonymity. - Or use any browser and enable above-mentioned TOR: Always mode may fix it also maybe. > any site on which you can submit any content needs to log your ID, meaning that you can track someone by ID across posts, across sites ... and as we've already established, you can tie that all to an IP. I would be interested if you can describe how exactly to do, it because no one yet explained that - [check this topic](/1TaLkFrMwvbNsooF4ioKAY9EuxTBTjipT/?Topic:1526907663_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS), i think researcher may work with posibility or probability of an IP matching to an identity (if he track some ID habits and pair it with debug.log connections), but can not be be sure about someone's IP. If you know the way to be 100% sure, please come with a way to fix this and talk to ZeroNet maintainer: https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ > Then there's the fact that it's based on torrents, but recommends using tor. Tor over torrents DoS's the network there is 8 years old article that talks about that: https://blog.torproject.org/bittorrent-over-tor-isnt-good-idea though unsure if this is still valid that zeronet transfers have any significant impact on Tor network (majority of the transferred content are relatively small files) Anyone who want to give back to the Tor network, [can setup Tor relay](/1LfvE91ZF18jdG3wW62Dw7NtfTZh737KPL/?Topic:1520962290_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS/Tor+The+Onion+Router+discussion) (last comment on the page) > There's also the issue of not enough encryption: site-public info (i.e. user submitted content) should be encrypted on the disk (even though everyone can have the key required to decrypt it). It may increase CPU utilization and possibly a bit RAM usage, though if that would be possible i would also prefer if certain data on HDD is encrypted by default. Though it is anyone responsibility to encrypt HDD if it contains sensitive data. I have ZeroNet data folder in an VeraCrypt encrypted container. Veracrypt can encrypt whole WIndows or Linux system drive.

> [caryoscelus](#comment_90_13oRBYqNeUr6Tvgt4KkAT9FT4XRiKFBjnE): Is there any list of id providers, by the way?

At least [here](/1TaLkFrMwvbNsooF4ioKAY9EuxTBTjipT/?Topic:1517337097_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS#comment_275_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS) are some i am aware about.

@leftside on Windows, NetLimitter software can limit an process bandwidth: https://alternativeto.net/software/netlimiter/
and apps like Process Hacker can set CPU and IO priority to the ZeroNet.exe process.

I am using HDD (much slower than SSD) and i am sharing alot of sites and data and my HDD utilization is not a problem (i am using external HDD, not system one). Sharing data with others mean reading from a drive and reading not decreasing your SSD drive life. Only writing does, as someone said.

Unfortunately i do not know what cause ZeroNet CPU usage, i do not have problem with that ATM. Some built in way to limit outgoing bandwidth and number of connections would be nice, for example when i am on 100kbit slow mobile internet :) but i agree if it is built in, it would result in a slower Zeronet which is not wanted.

1544277290_1BP5GrM5EDw9SVGmRJan1kvQ2DB2X.body:
@publicality Yes, i was also uneasy with this, not sure what is the cause, i got advice which i will describe below (i do not guarantee it is good advice and that it will work):

- go to [ZeroHello](/), click your username on the top and click show masterseed, copy it to safe place
- quit zeronet
- backup ZeroNet/data/users.json and then edit it so your main identity (you find it by searching for the masterseed copied earlier) is the first one among other identities.
- append new line to ZeroNet/zeronet.conf:
multiuser_local
(note you have to have MultiUser plugin not disabled in ZeroNet plugins folder. On Linux it is in ZeroNet/core/plugins i guess)
- start zeronet
- login your user account on the top of the [ZeroHello](/) using your masterseed you saved earlier
- quit ZN and start if after process disappear, maybe you will be logged in as your main ID by default..
Would appreciate feedback if it worked or what it did.

1544353154_1JcHMiQxXHX9q3ZK2LF9rZjvg3MUt.body:
> [blurhy](#comment_197_1JcHMiQxXHX9q3ZK2LF9rZjvg3MUtTpcK): Send request to other peers to query their database or search in files

i think the system should not work this way to utilize HDD and CPU of other people on demand of others and no captcha is unbreakable. Rather every peer who is using SearchPlugin should pre-create some index (maybe even located in memory) which can be then used to return results in matter of miliseconds. This index can be faked by bad peer so there may be the need for some consensus from multiple peers. The result from multiple peers can be calculated on the machine which requested the searching.

I do not know how DHT works, but maybe there can be some common table which will list common/frequently searched phrases and peers will be instructed to find results for these phrases. Some will return 1-10 results, some 11-21 result page..

- **Peers can supply fake info** or worthles pages, question is how to deal with that to return most relevant and useful results.
- Peer number is limitted, but number of content pages can be made almost unlimited (fake pages can be also created). So the **peers should not get overwhelmed by number of new sites and requests**.
- The SearchPlugin users that are on **low end mobile devices should not have problem with excessive CPU, RAM, disk utilization**.
- the amount of connections allowed should be limited and **transferred data should be minimal** (consider low bandwidth mobile devices - lets say 10KB/s BW limit)
- like with zeronet pr0xies, some people may want to contribute a server or more resources for the search plugin, so users will be able to edit plugin configuration to dedicate more resources for the search index building
- some mechanism to to find peers who supply fake data and de-prioritize them

Maybe the proposed way (to gather search results from any peer) is too ambitious. (because of no effective way to handle fake results, bad peers - Human user manually moderated blacklist (single point of failure) is very weak tool against b0tnet)
And better would be improving existing ZeroHello searcher to return the results (based on local files) faster?

Or @blurhy use Horizon as authority site, and will only manually approve trusted users/peers who will be allowed to contribute data?

Creating perfect zeronet's recaptcha is probably too dificult.

**If anyone interested, here are steps i did to successfuly replace incomplete file by complete:**

_Picked one complete optional big file on same site and backed it up including its msgpack file.
Then i deleted that optional big file including its msgpack file using ZeroHello/Files. Then reloaded page and clicked to play unavailable video, let it download part of the video, then disconnected internet.
Verified that the video is not fully playable. Backed up incomplete file. Paused site, replaced incomplete file by complete one from my backup.
Reloaded page to see video continue be only partialy playable even the file is complete.
Clicked "Check files" next to site on ZeroHello.
Site was trying to update main content.json, so i connected internet.
After 1 hour i returned back to PC to see that video is fully playable even after page reload. Good._

Do not know why but it started working even without tor browser work around

I removed tor (sudo apt remove tor), i went to Zeronet Docs: [how-to-make-zeronet-work-with-tor-under-linuxmacos](/1DocsYf2tZVVMEMJFHiDsppmFicZCWkVv1/faq/#how-to-make-zeronet-work-with-tor-under-linuxmacos) and followed the steps (especially the linked page of torproject.org where i navigated to page https://www.torproject.org/docs/debian.html.en#ubuntu (ubuntu in URL because i am using debian/ubuntu) where i followed tor installation instructions executing commands in root terminal ($ su)
While following instructions on above mentioned URLs i seen i had "ControlPort 9050" instead of 9051 in /etc/tor/torrc
Then i also additionally assigned "root" user into debian-tor group:
sudo usermod -a -G debian-tor root
Also i made sure my zeronet.conf file do not contains any "tor" lines:
tor_controller
tor_proxy

And after logout/login linux user, i see tor begin to work in Zeronet. (even tor service shows as "exited" which was confusing to me)

Possible causes:
- Maybe i used default tor in my OS repositories not latest one from official site
- i have not assigned root user into debian-tor group
- port number misconfiguration in /etc/tor/torrc & zeronet.conf

**UPDATE**: after computer restart problem is back

12 days later after reboot, i can not make it working. Again errors at ZN start:

[18:05:35] TorManager Tor controller connect error: IOError: [Errno 13] Permission denied: '/root/.tor/control_auth_cookie' in TorManager.py line 200
[18:05:35] TorManager Disabling Tor, because error while accessing Tor proxy at port 127.0.0.1:9050: No connection

tor/stable,now 0.3.5.7-1~d90.stretch+1 amd64 [installed]

tor seems to be running under user "root"
root and my user account under which i am running ZN is in "debian-tor" group ($ groups root; groups myusername)

-rw-r----- 1 root root 32 Jan 21 17:39 /root/.tor/control_auth_cookie

I booted into kernel Liquorix today and found that during boot the system complains it can not bind Tor to its 9050,51 port. Then i seen i am having a cronjob that launch Tor init script at boot. I removed it, rebooted and tor service started ok during boot time and zeronet also OK and detecting Tor as Available. So this discussion thread issue is **----> SOLVED now for me <----**.

today i have got this error again, out of sudden, after reading this thread what may helped was that i have defined
tor_controller = 127.0.0.1:9151
in zeronet.conf file, it was commented out (prefixed by \#)
on Windows port number may be different like 9051 or 9050
it can also help to:
sed -i "s|#ControlPort|ControlPort|g" /etc/tor/torrc;sed -i "s|#CookieAuthentication|CookieAuthentication|g" /etc/tor/torrc;sudo usermod -a -G debian-tor root 2>/dev/null
and restart computer!

> [james007](#comment_201_1DiRWRFXcVgQQ75cXnAG2pyxxjGo2VaH5): Firefox after Quantum ... suffer telemetry and tracking from Google

I think this is a hype. The page you linked is outdated and from what i found [here](https://github.com/mozilla/addons-frontend/issues/2785#issuecomment-315212909), the issue with google analytics is only it being used on about:addons page (and data was claimed to be anonymized) is no longer issue when [DoNotTrack is enabled](https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/how-do-i-turn-do-not-track-feature) (and i think every privacy oriented person has this by default, check this page: about:preferences#privacy)

> [st0ptr4ck1ngus](#comment_4_1P2V8C9A6T8ExWibrWqPdLoBnm5DnKMQe9): there are at least 10 references of firefox sending data back to google

I checked that about:config page, searching "google" and NOT found yours mentioned 10 entries indicating sending data to Google. If you mean Safe Browsing service, it can be disabled in Firefox options and i doubt Firefox is sending any really sensitive data to G. But thanks for posting it, because it is interesting to know that Google can be contacted and asked if certain site is malicious or not. Yours quoted text also does not show that there is some sensitive information transfer to Google.

Even in case of SafeBrowsing protection being enabled, FIrefox should not be sending any sensitive data per this article: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/how-does-phishing-and-malware-protection-work

"There are two times when Firefox will communicate with Mozilla’s partners while using Phishing and Malware Protection for sites. The first is during the regular updates to the lists of reporting phishing and malware sites. **No information about you or the sites you visit is communicated during list updates**. The second is in the event that you encounter a reported phishing or malware site. Before blocking the site, Firefox will request a double-check to ensure that the reported site has not been removed from the list since your last update. **This request does not include the address of the visited site**, it only contains partial information derived from the address. "

1548024035_131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5.body:
I can see my Windows NTFS partition under Linux... Linux can access it.
Yet i am using external NTFS HDD for my zeronet /data folder.
Regarding dual boot, backup your important data. Open disk management utility in WIndows and maybe shrink your windows partition to create space for new linux partition. Then create bootable linux USB drive, go to bios and set the usb flash disk as primary boot device, boot USB drive (F12 key for boot options), install Linux system creating new partition. Maybe read tutorials if you are not sure about something. I was able to resize system partitions later from within gparted bootable USB.

1552558114_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRF.body:
Maybe coincidence.
And also, (possibly not related), this is what Wikipedia says about "déjà vu":

"Mainstream scientific approaches reject the explanation of déjà vu as "precognition" or "prophecy," but rather explain it as an anomaly of memory, since despite the strong sense of recollection, the time, place, and practical context of the "previous" experience are uncertain or believed to be impossible.[9][10][11] Two types of déjà vu are recognized: the pathological déjà vu usually associated with epilepsy or that, when unusually prolonged or frequent, or associated with other symptoms such as hallucinations, may be an indicator of neurological or psychiatric illness,[12] and the non-pathological type characteristic of healthy people, about two-thirds of whom have had déjà vu experiences."

1552634420_1e2mHauMGG8GgSDvaaPrNanxvaxwp.body:
in 2018 [zeronet maintainer said](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/830#issuecomment-427215056) "almost all connections currently running on ECDHE-RSA-AES128-GCM-SHA256 TLSv1.2"
TLS ensures the data are not plain text as i understand it.
If you have Tor "available" in zeronet, then connections between you and other tor peers are encrypted.
To have encrypted traffic thru your city, country, ISP, use [VPN](/1LfvE91ZF18jdG3wW62Dw7NtfTZh737KPL/?Topic:1548340010_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS/How+to+setup+private+OpenVPN+on+a+Linux+server+and+Windows+Android+client).

When there is an option to show (single click or active by default) only new channels, categories, videos that match mentioned "tags of interest" - it can be useful for me to see only relevant new content without bothering to constantly repeat my searches to find which new content relevant to my interest was added. Youtube.com can track user browsing habits and show relevant videos, ZeroNet not doing this as it would not be eficient or possible. So there on the list of channels and categories and new videos from all users can help if user can turn on filtering only ones that match his defined tags of interest. > @thelegend27: possible work around so you can still use Tor?
> [nickwa](#comment_65_1EFZ3dYDWVpD4kF5H9PF83HjPAehEEKKJj): Use a VPN on top of TOR

Yes, i think the steps are to order [VPN server](/1LfvE91ZF18jdG3wW62Dw7NtfTZh737KPL/?Topic:1548340406_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS/How+do+i+setup+Ubuntu+VPS+to+remove+logs+run+as+OpenVPN+and+Zeronet+public+server) based in country where is not Tor ban. Connect VPN server and then the traffic goes encrypted (ISP or police can not know what data you transfer and if it is Tor) the data goes to your VPN server which is in safe country. Then server download and upload data on your behalf, you appear to have VPN server IP. Websites, etc. do not know you are in restricted country. Make sure to duck.com for VPN killswitch so you do not leak traffic outside of VPN tunnel.

> [quantumworld](#comment_312_1AdWXZdPUimpXoGNXUBde2CHR7gLf4onxE): How do you install plugins on zeronet?

Download plugin (usually .zip file), extract it and browse the directories to find some file with .py extension, navigate one level up, copy the folder into plugins directory of your zeronet.
On Windows, plugins directory is in ZeroNet/core/plugins/
Restart Zeronet

What does debug.log shows (make sure you [enable logging of everything](/Config)) when you attempt to load site using other peer IP http://127.0.0.1:43110/siteaddress/?zeronet_peer=8.7.6.5:12345  (12345 being fileserver port of the remote peer, local fileserver port can be found on [/Config](/Config) page or using "netstat -tulnp", you will want to run that on the server you are attempting to connect (zeronet_peer=8.7.6.5))

> [kai0](#comment_1017_1EZTWytasXcKdiUFnN4KHqAfvg1nwkTkKv): ping not to synchronize data

yes, but it can reveal if actual connection between servers work. also mine mentioned zeronet_peer parameter can reveal further information that can help find the cause of your issue (if zeronet connection between the peers work). Checking the debug.log will allow you to confirm if connection was made or if zeronet used other peer (i do not know if ?zeronet_peer parameter means ZN will use ONLY this peer or if it will prefer the peer).

i had similar problem like OP. some ideas what to do on zeronet:

because this OS allows user to access internet via VPN and then via Tor. That means that the school or internet provider can see only encrypted (unknown/unreadable) traffic (VPN tunnel) that goes to different country in which is the VPN server, from which traffic goes thru the Tor anonymization network to the destination which does not know ones real IP (if it is not leaked somehow thru insecure outdated web browser). 1561030213_1GJc2vm4vJjAKsFoFJ2D3gGmKiRac.body:
@xcape2net

i am not an expert, but this is what i think should be true, answering your questions:

> "file server port"

i think this is the "listening" port on which your computer accepting connections from other zeronet users (peers). Some users runs firewalls that blocks all traffic except allowed one, so they need to whitelist this port in firewall. (indication if this port is whitelisted/open is on the top of [ZeroHello](/)). This port can be defined in zeronet.conf or in [/Config](/Config).

> "peers ... only a tiny number from un-free places, like China"

sometimes i see China to be top country regarding peer count, yes i am also using custom tr@cker list as mentioned by klu9 earlier. You can find tr@cker lists searching on [ZeroHello](/).

> "how do you know the true top three countries that peers are located in"

we can not, because people are using proxies located in different countries than they live in

> "we probably don't know how many people are currently connected to ZeroNet, because there could be many trackers that we don't know about. But there must be a master list of trackers somewhere?"

i have same understanding. we can find big lists of tr@ckers in the clearnet, use duck.com i think these will be compatible with zeronet But i think only minority of ZN users are using custom trackers, so the connectable peer count may not increase significantly after adding these.

> "this tracker-peer hybrid mesh network makes ZeroNet a lot more subject to governmental control than I was thinking"

maybe not as much as one may think, because zeronet has nice 2 features i call peer exchange and tracker exchange. i do not know details, but you can search the zerotalk & zerome via [zerohello](/) Search in connected sites. In short zeronet makes sure that limitted amount of peers and trackers are automatically exchanged between zeronet users which should significantly limit problem that some government/ISP block all trackers and peers can not interconnect. People that have machine running 24/7 can [become ZN trackers by enabling bootstrapper plugin](/1BLogC9LN4oPDcruNz3qo1ysa133E9AGg8/?Post:135:Changelog:+August+28,+2018) - this plugin and mentioned exchanging features increases resilience against all trackers being blocked.

> [xcape2net](#comment_31_1GJc2vm4vJjAKsFoFJ2D3gGmKiRac2kfnz): When I try to go to duck.com ... are trackers and torrent trackers the same thing?

yes DDG. i think they are same - when i go to [/Stats](/Stats) page i can see normal [trackers](/1LX2wiouHctuUXtu5WkVM9TJJ3YoL6gAfm/?Page:zeronet-trackers) which people use for torrent clients (leechersParadise, internetwariors..) are there and seems to be working.

@xcape2net

> add trackers that are located in countries like South Africa and Australia that I would then see the peers in those countries

i think that the [tracker](/1LX2wiouHctuUXtu5WkVM9TJJ3YoL6gAfm/?Page:zeronet-trackers) location does not matter in order which peers you can connect. Usually peers can connect into any country/tracker and they doing it.

> I should be able to see everything on ZeroNet while just being connected to one tracker

yes, i think so, but on rare sites with lets say 1 or 2 online peers, maybe it can happen that these peers will not have your single tracker in their list.

> point of currently being connected to 13 trackers

trackers die or timeout from time to time, so good to have backup ones to keep high connectable peers count i think

> tracker lists with geographic locations

i do not know, you can try to duck.com it, phrase like "torrent trackers by country"

>  Do you know if it slows down my ZeroNet connection at all to use a lot of trackers?

- i am not a developer, so do not know how significant slow down high tracker count can mean. ZN maintainer said small count is sufficing and zero:// ones are better regarding bandwidth
- peer count depends on the day and hour, not always the same, also maybe depends on if Tor status (seen on ZeroHello - Tor: available" is the best i would guess) and i would guess also on port status (also seen on ZeroHello).

> [xcape2net](#comment_153_1GJc2vm4vJjAKsFoFJ2D3gGmKiRac2kfnz): When my STATS page says, "Connections     29 of 1535 peers".  Does that mean ... ?

check [this thread](/1TaLkFrMwvbNsooF4ioKAY9EuxTBTjipT/?Topic:1563567691_1GJc2vm4vJjAKsFoFJ2D3gGmKiRac2kfnz) on that topic

1559840057_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnX.body:
Here is how i migrated from ZeroNet py2 to py3 on MS Windows today. So far there does not seem to be problem.

0. stopped zeronet and made sure it is not running
1. Downloaded the windows archive mentioned on the bottom of the http://127.0.0.1:43110/1BLogC9LN4oPDcruNz3qo1ysa133E9AGg8/?Post:146:Changelog:+June+6,+2019
2. extract it in same folder like current ZeroNet folder. In my case it was:
C:\ZeroNet\ (old folder)
C:\ZeroNet-win-dist-win64\ (newly extracted files)
3. Move "data" folder from old to new folder (C:\ZeroNet\data -> C:\ZeroNet-win-dist-win64\data) 
4. If you have manually enabled some plugins or installed new, make sure to enable plugins (rename their folder/s) also in new zeronet folder (C:\ZeroNet-win-dist-win64\core\plugins)
5. copy zeronet.conf from old to new folder and open it for editing. **Make sure there is no line containing "open_browser" (in my case zeronet not started indicating the error in log/error.log file: [line 10]: option 'open_browser' in section 'global' already exists
(i had open_browser set to false in zeronet.conf) @nofish:**

> [myriri](#comment_22_145qVnMUHFaHhDNmmd1s2ZPh5FTArtZmjn): Ok now I'm confused.So whats this site?http://127.0.0.1:43110/1ADQAHsqsie5PBeQhQgjcKmUu3qdPFg6aA/

This is Millchan. The site without merger feature. It is the site 08chan was clonned from and Millchan has more up to date code. The site with merger feature is called [Millchan engine or Millchan merger](/17gCoQDCAAoQkzKRiajFNUAhnVD2gSNmuC). You will likely see no boards on MC Engine, because you need to first visit some board site (aka "hub"), you can find one when you click the link "Example hub" on [this page](/1ADQAHsqsie5PBeQhQgjcKmUu3qdPFg6aA/?:users/12NPW6WLFBLVivNGqijcfktARobftfLFAN:dev:1b5f282e-6a57-4aa4-ae11-8b85dda51509) where is MC engine introduced. The link is on the bottom of the first post. That Example hub will add new board to the Millchan engine site and inside the board you can find a topic with more boards and a guide how to setup your own discussion board.

> [myriri](#comment_23_145qVnMUHFaHhDNmmd1s2ZPh5FTArtZmjn): can't add sites to the merger hub thing by visiting the non-merger millchan?
Unsure if i understand. Browsing non-merger Millchan site will not add any hub to the Millchan Engine site. Only when you visit special zeronet site that is a Millchan Engine hub (or also called merger site), then i think you should be prompted whether you want to add it to the Millchan Engine. Once added, new board will appear in the list or Millchan Engine boards.

> [toyata](#comment_82_17mM4YqSx7nMkYcePZB2GWcJBzkogWpqA1): 1277.33 MB optional files, which one could help distribute, is that supposed to be all?
no. complete site, before self-signed certificate was removed from cert_signers, has more than 30GB of optional files. It seems like new users currently does not have access to the majority of the content that is signed/owned by the self-signed identities. @08admin: disallowed all self-signed identities by removing line:
   "08chan": ["1NwwLdiFBcVAA4jXQ712ZtQfDHEMvk8BiD"]
from cert_signers in data/users/content.json
admin can enable it again until he finds some anti-spam solution or he may (not sure if possible) also [manually whitelist existing self-signed identities](/1DdPHedr5Tz55EtQWxqvsbEXPdc4uCVi9D/?:users/13E1NfoEM9eYfxk3mZQTLW5qYBekTp5W7v:v:494e061f-6677-477a-9d49-55bffc20a07b#post-c8dbed68-5c2a-4c40-a49d-bd5ac34edf4b) and ban rest (not mentioned/whitelisted) - to prevent new spam bots.

> [toyata](#comment_83_17mM4YqSx7nMkYcePZB2GWcJBzkogWpqA1): content, which now is inaccessible due

yes. as i understand it, content should still exist on various peer's computers (if they do not delete the site), but that content is not allowed to be seen to a new users, maybe until these people with self-signed IDs switch to zeroid or until admin allow existing content of the people who remain just self-signed.

> if 08chan would be converted to a merger site

[millchan](/1ADQAHsqsie5PBeQhQgjcKmUu3qdPFg6aA/) and [millchan engine(or called merger)](/1ADQAHsqsie5PBeQhQgjcKmUu3qdPFg6aA/?:users/12NPW6WLFBLVivNGqijcfktARobftfLFAN:dev:1b5f282e-6a57-4aa4-ae11-8b85dda51509) are different systems (different code. even site looks same). But this is interesting idea - the conversion, it depends on admin when he get time or if he like to do it or if that is good idea. Millchan Engine already exist and people can use it and even clone it. Regarding millchan Engine function, i think you understand it well. Owners of the boards in the Millchan engine have absolute power above their boards because boards are separate sites. So the site owner can enable any certificate authority including self-signed.

maybe soon @08admin: will try to apply [this IDEA](/1DdPHedr5Tz55EtQWxqvsbEXPdc4uCVi9D/?:users/13E1NfoEM9eYfxk3mZQTLW5qYBekTp5W7v:v:494e061f-6677-477a-9d49-55bffc20a07b#post-c8dbed68-5c2a-4c40-a49d-bd5ac34edf4b) on how to fix the site. **It worked** apparently for me and other user. But better to wait for admin than messing with the site maybe. The work around is about marking site as own (on 08chan, corner button dragging to the left and scrolling to the bottom of the menu, clicking "This is my site") which should disable updates of the site core files. Then replacing 08chan ...zeronet/data/1DdPHedr5Tz55EtQWxqvsbEXPdc4uCVi9D/data/users/content.json file contents shown [here](/17iF64gTLycSohUSJsFyq7FMYsQfMqghJa/?1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS_1) (you have to first download [whole site](/17iF64gTLycSohUSJsFyq7FMYsQfMqghJa) before you will see that contents, may need to reload page). Then again from the 08chan site clicking button to "Sign and publish" changes made in the file). It will fail to publish because file is not authorized, but it should start loading all the 2K users self-signed content.

I have not tested if new self-signed IDs will be able to post (that was admin's aim to prevent SPAM from new self-signed IDs). if admin will apply the update, those who applied this patch should not forget to untick "this is my site" option in 08chan to get all updates.

Do not delete the site, preserve your file uploads.

1565403304_1D9oYXWZH2S55PeoCFDKTqq8roNXq.body:
When Tor is working in "available" mode (default), then it should also work in always mode.
If it does not work, it should show an error code (on the top of the ZeroHello). The Tor button on ZeroHello has a link to instructions on how Tor need to be configured.

I also had problems with Tor (i think it was on MS Windows) and a workaround was to launch Tor browser and then use its Tor by defining tor controller and tor proxy as mentioned in previous comment by crazylime.
Unsure what is the crazylime error, because he written too much texts. I usually add errors i get into search engine duck.com or into zerohello "Search in connected sites".

> --tor_proxy 127.0.0.1:9150 --tor_controller 127.0.0.1:9151
i bet this is valid only for Linux, because Windows Tor may be using different ports 9050, 9051

@xcape2net: Maybe additional switch would make the python command more solid?:
--tor always (to connect only onion - tor peers anonymously and securely)
or
--tor enable (to allow also non tor peer connections)

> [xcape2net](#comment_265_1GJc2vm4vJjAKsFoFJ2D3gGmKiRac2kfnz): using the TOR browser, your IP address is hidden. Having to take the additional step of setting TOR Always doesn't make sense to me

i think that you do not need to care much about this. **What is important is if on [ZeroHello](/) you can see "Tor: always" or "Tor: available" - that i assume means Zeronet can and will (if there is no bug in the ZN code) use Tor.**

Also read what Zeronet developer (nofish) says about Tor modes - [here](/1TaLkFrMwvbNsooF4ioKAY9EuxTBTjipT/?Topic:1520915070_1b4WB9mZcpjKdQUnYvGBgTMeatTxXTBnf).

If ZN will not load in your Tor Browser but load in normal browser, then you have to do proxy adjustment in Tor browser, as you described a few comments earlier. By such adjustment, you do not break tor connection/anonymity, it just (according to my opinion) removed problem where you can not load localhost IP via Tor network (does not mean deanonymization).

> [xcape2net](#comment_272_1GJc2vm4vJjAKsFoFJ2D3gGmKiRac2kfnz): Did you interpret that differently?
no ;)

So did Tor: always started working? If yes, please post what helped. If not, please post errors from zeronet/log/debug.log and your /var/log/tor* (in case you are under Linux) and why do you think it is not working. I am asking because i think this thread should end with your comment where you describe how you have solved the issue you asked in your first post. Or at least if there is any (even not optimal) workaround. So future people can quickly find something helpful.

1565456974_1D9oYXWZH2S55PeoCFDKTqq8roNXq.body:
** How to stick the topic on zerotalk cloned site**

I was looking up the answer one year back maybe. I tried to search (using [Zerohello](/) site, Search in connected sites), but can not find. Though it is on Github: https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroTalk/issues/47
(you have to open your site files - corner button moving to the left and clicking appropriate link to open the directory) and edit main/root content.json file where you find:
 "settings": {
and on the new line add:
  "topic_sticky_uris": ["2_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj", "8_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj"]

(update the strings to match topic/s address)
For one topic, it will be:
  "topic_sticky_uris": ["2_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj"]

Zeronet should ask you to sign and publish the modified file.

**Administration of the ZeroTalk forum**

Note that some admin features are claimed to be added to [this zerotalk clone](/1EgyL4nj9DmeSSQg3fytxGJjihxtmMon5y) by @Geekless

You can edit your site main content.json file and replace zerotalk address next to "clonned_from" to 1EgyL4nj9DmeSSQg3fytxGJjihxtmMon5y and then on ZeroHello, site list, click three dots next to your site and select Upgrade. It should reset all your site files to the new versions to match 1Egy site code.

Btw. there are also a few other [zerotalk cl0nes](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1TaLkFrMwvbNsooF4ioKAY9EuxTBTjipT/?Topic:1548256806_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS)

1565705375_1NVRyK6ptrG3XmmvMp5WEcxfjeeLa.body:
You can [enable Multiuser plugin](/Plugins)
Then you switch identities via the USER button on the top of the ZeroHello site.

Your followed topics will not go with you (unless you manually copy it to your new identity by editting zeronet/users.json).

Link works possibly only in newer [python3 zeronet](/1TaLkFrMwvbNsooF4ioKAY9EuxTBTjipT/?Topic:1559840057_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS). in older zeronet, you have to enable plugin by going to zeronet/plugins or zeronet/core/plugins directory and rename directory "disabled-Multiuser" to "Multiuser". Restart ZN.

If you want to really **delete your data on some site** . I guess you have to empty zeronet/data/siteaddress/data/users/youpublickey/data.json file (or edit it) and then go to site menu (corner button moved to the left) scroll down "This is my site" and into CONTENT PUBLISHING field add: data/users/youpublickey/content.json
Sign and publish.

1565658736_1KUSKrffaR1sfLwxZUXUPshLpKhh5.body:
i think user submitted data can be only placed in the database which sites like this one is using. the database is decentralized, all peers has it downloaded. Maybe you can make the content not visible on site, but it will still be in the database. how long you can leave zeronet closed without your site become peer-less depends on count of peers you gather. I do not think that the **GDPR** is a step in a wrong direction regarding privacy. Quoting from the [EFF document](https://www.eff.org/files/2019/12/11/behind_the_one-way_mirror-a_deep_dive_into_the_technology_of_corporate_surveillance.pdf):
"The General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) in the European Union gives those it covers the right to access and delete information that’s been collected about them. It also requires companies to have a legitimate reason to use data, which could come from a “legitimate interest” or opt-in consent. The GDPR is far from perfect, and its effectiveness will depend on how regulators and courts implement it in the years to come. But it gives meaningful rights to users and prescribes real consequences for companies who violate them."

1584836844_1EVRj1cizACuJXsBGLRGSvTMYG7Mk.body:
Hiding clearnet connection, is that possible (except Tor)? You can encrypt the data that you are transfering (openvpn, wireguard, shadowsocks, ssh socks does it), but it has to go from you to the target server (proxy), you can use multiple relay servers to make it hard to connect you and the exit proxy server. Another issue is your [web browser f00tprint](/1LfvE91ZF18jdG3wW62Dw7NtfTZh737KPL/?Topic:1544691845_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS/Browser+fingerprint+should+i+be+concerned+about+it) that can allow pairing your activities on various sites.
If you want to anonymize your proxy/VPN, [here is some tutorial](/1LfvE91ZF18jdG3wW62Dw7NtfTZh737KPL/?Topic:1517258702_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS/What+is+the+good+setup+for+anonymous+secure+internet+usage). And [here is the 8chan discussion about VPN providers](/1DdPHedr5Tz55EtQWxqvsbEXPdc4uCVi9D/?:users/14r48CcSSyoNo1PNhy6uWriqpopMUfqfUX:tech:3c2b7f17-b314-4f4d-a8e3-fd0d9c9086dc).

1584867258_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnX.body:
> [soros2020](#comment_1_15NgM1u7cfVeBm4kuHVZ3kQ2a66x35LUKY): @ssdifnskdjfnsdjk     hi  Sorry I am fucked with the torjan , I saw every html files were embedding in to these code "DropFileName = "svchost.exe""  and what should I do?

**What You can do when malware modified your files?** I do not know which OS do you have, but you can use tools like Notepad++ or PSPad or other that allows searching inside the files. You define your HDD path (for example C:\) and search inside the files for "VBScript" or other unique string found in the malicious code. It will find potential bad files, you may check its modification time and see how many other files are modified around that time, check other such files contents. You can also use mentioned SW to do actual replacement in the files. You should firs try the search and replace function on single file that you will first backup. You should first remobe the trojan (search symptoms and you may find removal instructions on the internet). If you are unsure that you removed it, then you should possibly backup all data and install clean OS. And then install only verified open source software and suspicious run in the sandbox (there are apps for that). Do not forget Antivirus SW and scaning software binaries before you first run these using virustotal.com (they have desktop app for scanning).

**Regarding removal of bad code in your zites**, you can find it using mentioned software and remove bad code. Save changes and then publish changes from within your site 0 menu (drag the top right corner button to the left) and scroll down and sign both content.json files using the private key which you can find in your zeronet/data/users.json file near your site address...

@1bfqutudhtexlka i have read that tutorial and i think that i followed it exactly. So i created non-root user on my Debian Linux:
adduser user
usermod -aG sudo,debian-tor user
If i want to try running ZN under this new user (i have no clue why it should work and root user not) only thing to do is to modify ownership of the zeronet directory contents: chown -R user:user /home/zeronet ?
I just tried that but tor continue to fail (service tor restart;service tor status):
systemd[1]: tor.service: Failed to set invocation ID on control group /system.slice/tor.service, ignoring: Operation not permitted

grep -v "#" /etc/tor/torrc

ControlPort 9051
CookieAuthentication 1

DataDirectoryGroupReadable 1
CacheDirectoryGroupReadable 1
CookieAuthFileGroupReadable 1
CookieAuthFile /var/lib/tor/control_auth_cookie

(/var/lib/tor/control_auth_cookie does not exist, but creating it with debian-tor rights does not help, unsure about chmod permissions)

Also if i run ZN  (/bin/bash ZeroNet.sh) not as root, but under "user" then ZN fails saying "Ui.UiServer Web interface bind error, must be running already, exiting.... [Errno 13] Permission denied: ('0.0.0.0', 80)" (yes i defined that ZN be accessible at port 80 in zeronet.conf - ui_port = 80 - i read that i need su privilege to bind to 1024 and lower port numbers. When i defined ui_port to 8080 then it worked)

But the problem with Tor continue (Errno 111) Connection refused

> (Errno 111) Connection refused

i think that this error meant that the ZN was unable to connect the control port, after changing the port number from 9151 to 9051 in zeronet.conf, and restart ZN, **ZN connects tor OK** 🙂.

tor_controller = 127.0.0.1:9051

that is the only "tor" line in my zeronet.conf

i have also verified i have [tor settings like this](https://wiki.archlinux.org/title/ZeroNet), but no change was needed.

Another thing to try is Linux command:
sed -i "s|#ControlPort|ControlPort|g" /etc/tor/torrc;sed -i "s|#CookieAuthentication|CookieAuthentication|g" /etc/tor/torrc;sudo usermod -a -G debian-tor root 2>/dev/null
and then restart computer to apply permission change.

Hi, when i add someone's certificate, how can i then find him on my People tab, so i can send my cert. him privately via Retroshare mail?
// Answering my own question: After submitting the key, the Add user dialog should detect/prefix the username before the brackets. Then you can enter this name on the People tab, click use and then click "Send invite" button under user's avatar image. After they accept it (add my key), i assume it means we can interconnect, search, share files...

If You are on Linux and not yet running I2P anonymity in Retroshare, [this article may help you to install i2P](/1LfvE91ZF18jdG3wW62Dw7NtfTZh737KPL/?Topic:1622561384_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS/). Retroshare then automatically detected it in Preferences/Network/Hidden service configuration.

1624144633_1KhfhSvSnonDqSgVk8B6Cg5WE2u2Z.body:
> a way to solve that ?
ZN development is idle now.
Did you try [ZeroHello](/) right sites menu and three dots next to that site, menu option "Check files"?, also do Update menu option under that three dots menu. Maybe it will sync. Second thing to try is to restart ZN, third thing is to publish again, fourth thing is to delete incomplete site and let it re-download (if other computer has the full site).

Note that you can drag and drop the top-right corner button to the left and to the bottom, it will show some more details about what is going on. Also you can check your ZN log, or enable debug mode in zeronet.conf to log more verbose.

two things (that may not work):

sad moments in ZeroNet:
- @Git Center inactive
- @Krixano stopped his zites development, [FYI Krixano is deleting their older zites](/1TaLkFrMwvbNsooF4ioKAY9EuxTBTjipT/?Topic:1557305635_16HcyFK8526ZYJBKPpSDCbpJv6WWBNvENj)

good moments:

- nofish not dead yet

United States 26805 peers
China 13358 peers
United Kingdom 4733 peers
Canada 4049 peers
...
**Russia 2675 peers**
(e.g. chinese peers can use e.g. US proxy, so it can not tell you exact nationality of the users)

I have solved the issue of this topic. First F12 (developer console):
i have tried to shutdown ZN, backup ZN/data/users.json, rename my site directory in ZN/data/ and start ZN, visit ZN site. I see "Connecting..." and log errors:
```
Uncaught TypeError: rules is null all.js
Uncaught TypeError: topic.topic_creator_user_name is null all.js
ERROR - Unhandled exception: KeyError: 'content.json' in <gevent>/greenlet.py line 766 > Worker.py line 208 > 154 > BigfilePlugin.py line 404 > ContentManager.py line 1006 > 980 > 790 > ContentDbDict.py line 61 > 34
ERROR Site:... WebSocket handleRequest error: KeyError: 'content.json' in UiWebsocket.py line 80 > 236 > SidebarPlugin.py line 531 > 197 > ContentManager.py line 348 > ContentDbDict.py line 61 > 34
ERROR Db#1:Chart Commit error: OperationalError: cannot commit - no transaction is active in Db.py line 169 (reason: Interval)
```

then the **solution was**:
shutdown ZN
backup users.json
backup site dir. in ZN/data/siteaddress
start ZN
go to site, copy its address, drag & drop corner 0 button to the left, scroll down the menu and click to Delete site. After site was deleted (redirect to ZeroHello), open the site again, it loaded OK, needed to wait a minute or so and did Shift+F5 to reload the site without cache. If you are owner of the site, you can open site's menu as described above, scroll down the menu and enable This is my site. ZN may recover the private key from masterseed.

btw. can anyone please try to post a test topic to [that site](/19Q64E6Gt67e96skgYSJejYjFRrJYyqP2t/) if publishing succeed?

@insurgo
i am using following code to keep my clone up to date with the github repo:
```
giturl="https://github.com/zeronet-enhanced/ZeroNet.git"
dstdir=~/apps/zeronet
if [[ ! -d "$dstdir" ]]; then git clone "$giturl" "$dstdir" && cd "$dstdir"||exit; else
cd "$dstdir"||exit;git remote add origin "$giturl" 2>/dev/null;git submodule update --init --recursive;git pull origin master 2>/dev/null||git pull origin main 2>/dev/null
fi
```

I suggest you to check my tutorial on setting up ZN on a Linux VPS, it is under point 5 on [this page](/1LfvE91ZF18jdG3wW62Dw7NtfTZh737KPL/?Topic:1548340406_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS/How+do+i+setup+Ubuntu+VPS+as+a+OpenVPN+and+Zeronet+public+server+setup+logs+removal), though it may also waste some of your time or confuse you. It talks about GFW so if you are behind it, so it may be the cause. Some Tor/tracker settings are at [/Config](/Config).
Check your log/debug.log or logs/debug.log. It may tell you what is wrong with networking (if you need more details in the log, then in /Config enable Logging of everything. Also on the top of the [ZeroHello](/) you can see several buttons, all these contains related information to connectivity so that can also give a clue. Some errors on site are fixed by waiting a minute or several and reloading page.

@haxorz
Hopefully you are running latest version or zeronet-enhanced.
Your Tor was disabled on that image, for more peers is better to make sure it shows: available or enabled.
TOR is not working at all?  -> you need to focus on the error message it is giving to you in the debug.log or maybe even on ZeroHelllo button on the top and search that error on ZeroHello search field (if you have downloaded zerotalk site). 
Also you have likely read the tutorial in zeronet docs on how to setup Tor properly.

In order to load Syncronite trackers, you have to visit that zite and load it.

"Connection reset by peer" suggests that your computer is not the problem in this connection, though i am unsure if it is reliable claim.

> Maybe the provider could block these somehow

not likely, unless maybe in China? (i read that they have made some actions against ZN)

Good to see someone who not give up and make effort to run ZN..

@haxorz I do not see if you have mentioned on which platform you are running ZN. If on Linux, your following statement is wrong likely:

> TOR should be properly implemented in the latest version

Because You need to install Tor on Linux (i think i do not need to mention how, search engine query: mylinuxdistributionname install tor) and make sure the /etc/tor/torrc is properly configured & Tor running. ZeroHello tor button links to instructions i think and it is in the documentation.

> now it looks like this: https://i.ibb.co/RP1Fg9d/zn.jpg

i have not mentioned it? You need to search this error code on ZeroHello page search box (after you have downloaded ZeroTalk site. There are topics about this.

@haxorz when You search ZN for that Tor OK status (your second image) maybe you'll find my post or other posts. When you check your debug log (or drag & drop the corner button down), you will see if tor related connections (.onion) etc. works (depends on your log level set in [/Config](/Config)). v2 onion warnings are OK, it is just warning you/ZN is using outdated V2 onion. > [ibudder](#comment_1_18DQw1RXP4gQcqPcYrxZEPzc55fXAv16eQ):  come aross ilegal p*rn a cop isn't gonna show up on my door right?

Except what mentioned musickiller i would suggest not clicking Help distribute all files kind of option on sites. That will prevent download and distribution of files you have never seen. But many static sites works the way it downloads all content, not just the one seen on the page you have visited. On big user contributed sites, they are using "optional files" which means user contributed files (images, videos) will be downloaded only when requested on page you have landed. So when some image is bad, you can delete it onsite or manually by its name from HDD. Mute the user, Delete whole site, block the site from displaying again. And if you are worried about police, [use good VPN](/1DdPHedr5Tz55EtQWxqvsbEXPdc4uCVi9D/?:users/14r48CcSSyoNo1PNhy6uWriqpopMUfqfUX:tech:3c2b7f17-b314-4f4d-a8e3-fd0d9c9086dc) or enable Tor:Always mode on [ZeroHello](/) site so you benefit from Tor anonymity.

1637282161_16zLpbqTz9hpy6E2oH3y7tHNiTyVs.body:
Yes, maybe ZeroID is dead, you may check web browser developer console (F12 ?) Console & Network tabs to see any detail about the action errors.
Alternative on ZeroID is [Kxoid](/12F5SvxoPR128aiudte78h8pY7mobroG6V) which may be supported on ZeroTalk. [Other zites](/1Kt7xxVRcxHcK14Mt7YZdXfh8MzUJMkvpk/) may also be using different IDs like Kaffie or self signed.
To kill ZN, you may prepend similar line like following (replace path by yours after checking "ps aux|grep ero") to your ~/.bashrc file
`alias znkill='for pid in $(pidof runtime/bin/python3 /home/$(whoami)/apps/zeronet/zeronet.py); do echo "Term&kill, 6 seconds..." && kill $pid && sleep 6 && kill -9 $pid; done'`
And in new terminal session run command "znkill"

> [inis](#comment_7_16zLpbqTz9hpy6E2oH3y7tHNiTyVsB4RiQ): Why killing $pid twice?

First should be terminate signal and second actually kill the process if not exited in 6 seconds (not likely to happen for ZN i guess, though i guess that for some processes TERM signal may allow to exit more properly than KILL)

> [inis](#comment_11_16zLpbqTz9hpy6E2oH3y7tHNiTyVsB4RiQ): In multiuser mode the interface shows a label next to the three dots, with what looks like a temporary user:

Once identity changes thanks to multiuser, then you can register new ID on various ID providers like kxoid, kaffie, millchan self signed ID etc. You should save your masterkey so you can return back to the identity of your choice.
By using different identity you will not see old IDs notifications of followed topics etc. on ZeroHello. You will see only ones created under new IDs.
